destination.label: Hong Kong
destination.title: And if Manhattan were in China?

content.intro:
Anyone who arrives in Hong Kong for the first time cannot help but see in it an Asian New York. But after this first impression, Hong Kong has many unexpected surprises in store.

In Hong Kong, you will discover that there is more countryside than skyscrapers. That's the first surprise! The second is that, in Hong Kong, you will enjoy a taste of the same China that you would encounter on the other side of the border, on the mainland. For the West did not kill the East, and while the Maoists destroyed Beijing, Hong Kong maintained its Chinese roots. Although the city worships at the altar of unbridled capitalism, Hong Kong also has more than 600 temples, including 300 dedicated to Tin Hau, goddess of the sky and the sea. Another surprise!

The British are gone, but the double-decker bus and savoury canapés at 'five o'clock tea made in Peninsula' remain. Here, helicopters and racehorses can be found on the roofs of skyscrapers. Cranes pop up like mushrooms, their wild visual poetry building the largest area of polders in the world. People love the sea so much here that they'll eat anything that comes from it. Here, you will feast, as in very few places in the world of gastronomy, on cuisines from all around the globe. The flavours of each region and country are more intense, but it does not preclude the simmering fusion cuisine of tomorrow. Hong Kong is a cinematic city par excellence, manufacturing images that suit everyone's taste: from ultra-violent and art-house movies to romances that draw more tears than the water in the Pearl River. Do movies use Hong Kong as a mere backdrop or does Hong Kong make itself into the city it sees on the movie screen? All we know is that its production industry was the third largest in the world before the retrocession, so much so that Jackie Chan and Michelle Yeoh have made their way to the big and small screens of tens of millions of fans in China, Malaysia, the Philippines…

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in Hong Kong

seoData.seoTitle: And if Manhattan were in China? - Hong Kong Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Anyone who arrives in Hong Kong for the first time cannot help but see in it an Asian New York. But after this first impression, Hong Kong has many unexpected surprises in store.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Hong Kong

weather.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Hong Kong

content.title: Tai O, explore an authentic fishing village

introduction.small: On the far west of Hong Kong, on the coast of Lantau Island, the village of Tai O retained its aspect and traditions over time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tai O, explore an authentic fishing village

paragraphs.text:
While Hong Kong reveals urban landscapes worthy of a science fiction movie in some neighbourhoods, the Tai O village seems stuck in the past. With no traffic nor skyscrapers around, locals come and enjoy the place's peaceful atmosphere, on the western part of Lantau Island. Nicknamed the “Venice of Hong Kong”, it is a Tanka village, housing a community of fishermen living above water in houses on stilts. Each house leads to a ladder and its own small boat moored to it.

Today, as it used to be, the local industry remains fishing. Fish and seafood are piled up on market stalls. Restaurants serve the catch of the day at bargain prices. In Tai O, the line keeps growing longer to taste egg waffles – the best of all Hong Kong. After a visit of the village and its 17th-century Yeung Hau Temple, take the boat for an aquatic journey in between stilts all the way to the open sea, where you will be able to observe pink dolphins.

Tai O Village
Lantau Island
Hong Kong

content.title: John Anthony gives dim sum a kick

introduction.small: Canton and Sichuan meet under the guidance of the most British of all Hongkongers. Revisited dim sum and barbecue await!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: John Anthony gives dim sum a kick

paragraphs.text:
In 1805, John Anthony became the first Chinaman to receive British citizenship. The restaurant carrying his name thus pays tribute to a cultural crossroad, between London's East End and 1920s Shanghai.

In an elegant setting devised with an ecofriendly mindset, paralleling the evolution of Chinese society, get ready for a surprising culinary journey: it is quite a tricky mission to try and transform Cantonese cuisine, at it is mainly based off traditional recipes, but John Anthony passes the test with style. Revisited dishes include dim sum (grilled Iberian pork belly served with marinated seaweed) and barbecue (Australian Wagyu char siu with a green onion sauce) and meet in Sichuan for some spicier flings.

This sophistication finds its completion in an incredible gin collection, perhaps the most extensive of the entire former British colony. A must for all spirit lovers.

John Anthony
Basement Level, Lee Garden Three, 1 Sunning Road
Causeway Bay
Hong Kong

+852 2898 3788

http://johnanthony.hk/

Menu: from 300 HKD

content.title: Ovolo Southside, industrial chic style

introduction.small: Close to Ocean Park, Ovolo Southside successfully turned a 40-year-old industrial building into a charmingly raw hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ovolo Southside, industrial chic style

paragraphs.text:
In the south of Hong Kong, facing Lamma Island, the Wong Chuk Hang neighbourhood is gradually turning into a cultural and artistic hotspot, with art galleries, creative agencies and trendy coffee shops. This is where Ovolo Southside set up home, creating the first boutique hotel of the “Pearl of the East”, using an old industrial building as its base – a rare fact in a metropolis where skyscrapers grow like grass.

Each of the 23 floors was arranged with a New York mindset: incredible ceiling heights, large picture windows, works of art scattered here and there, stylish furniture of modern mid-century inspiration.

At Kömune, the hotel restaurant, food lovers will revel in the famous Wagyu rib served with sautéed broccolini, or the wild mushroom crostini with butter truffle and parmesan. When night sets in, climb up to the rooftop where you will enjoy unobstructed views over Ocean Park, all the way to Repulse Bay and the China Sea.

Ovolo Southside
64 Wong Chuk Hang Road
Southside
Hong Kong

+852 3460 8100

https://ovolohotels.com.hk/ovolosouthside/

Rooms: from 900 HKD

content.title: Dr. Fern's Gin Parlour, no prescription required

introduction.small: Enter Dr. Fern's Gin Parlour, a “medical practice” of a new kind...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dr. Fern's Gin Parlour, no prescription required

paragraphs.text:
Enjoying perfect location in the centre of Hong Kong, this speakeasy keeps its cards close to its chest: you have to push the doors of a medical practice to discover the warm and cosy atmosphere that awaits you inside. The attentive barmen all wear white coats and have been assigned with the task of treating stress and anxiety with the best gins in the world, there available in 250 kinds, making it the largest selection of all Hong Kong.
Order the classic yet perfectly balanced G&Ts, martinis and negronis, or choose subtly flavoured creations. Fresh aromatic herbs and plant extracts make the basis of all drinks (as the place's name suggests). For those who may not be so keen on juniper, wines and other alcoholic beverages are available.
Snacks, sandwiches and salads are served for lunch, coffee and seasonal tea in the afternoon, and gin, obviously, any time of day or night. To be enjoyed in moderation!

Dr. Fern's Gin Parlour
Shop B31A, First Basement Floor
Landmark Atrium, 15 Queen's Road
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2111 9449

Cocktails: from 90 HKD

https://mingfathouse.com/restaurants/dr-ferns/

content.title: Frantzén's Kitchen, high-quality Nordic gastronomy with Asian influences

introduction.small: Nordic gastronomy takes over Hong Kong at Frantzén's Kitchen, three-starred Swedish chef Björn Frantzén's new restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frantzén's Kitchen, high-quality Nordic gastronomy with Asian influences

paragraphs.text:
With its cosy Scandinavian environment, typical of the hygge trend - or Nordic sense of well-being - Frantzén's Kitchen claims up the unique model of an innovative Swedish cuisine in Hong Kong. The intimate dining room seats 30 patrons and provides heart-warming atmosphere in a decor made of wood, mouse grey panels as well as burgundy lamps and chairs.
Displayed in enamelled stoneware, dishes play the quality card and the mix of complex flavours, like the "Swedish Sushi", subtle blend of venison and bird liver, topped with lichen chips. A few Asian touches find their spot here and there, in the caramelized cod in miso, the grilled Swedish beef tenderloin with smoked shiitake and enoki mushrooms. Little used ingredients also find their way into the desserts, with thyme ice cream, tomato jam, pollen and birch oil. This revolution of flavours and textures will leave you a lasting impression!

Frantzén's Kitchen
11 Upper Station Street
Sheung Wan
Hong Kong

+852 2559 8508

www.frantzenskitchen.com

Menu: around 480 HKD

content.title: Happy Paradise, headed towards the 1980s!

introduction.small: In the SoHo district, Happy Paradise unveils unique neo-Chinese cuisine in a funky atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Happy Paradise, headed towards the 1980s!

paragraphs.text:
The neon lights that run along the ceiling illuminate the room with a soft pink and blue glow. In a psychedelic setting, an allusion to the 1980s flows. Sitting between tropical plants at the Formica tables with retro chairs, ears listening to pop music of the time, you will feel as if you've travelled in time. Only the contents of your plate will bring you back to the present: chef May Chow, very popular in Hong Kong, reinvents Cantonese cuisine for a contemporary result, with a hint of nostalgia. Try the char siu, a must-try in Chinese cuisine, made here with Iberian pork and silky egg whites, glazed with soy sauce, or the Australian Wagyu skirt steak served with fried rice noodles, seaweed butter and preserved lemon. You can also be guided by the chef by opting for the surprise menu, for a blind discovery of Hong Kong's culinary paradise.

Happy Paradise
52-56 Staunton Street
UG/F Central
Hong Kong

+852 2816 2118

https://www.happyparadise.hk/

Menu: around 354 HKD

content.title: The Fleming, a hotel in homage to the Star Ferry

introduction.small: Located in the vibrant district of Wan Chai, The Fleming brings Hong Kong's legendary boat crossing from one end of the Victoria Harbour to the other to life through its boutique hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Fleming, a hotel in homage to the Star Ferry

paragraphs.text:
The maritime decoration is full of symbols, from travels, the community and tradition. These terms, which also characterize Hong Kong, have been captured by The Fleming. The design of this boutique hotel is largely inspired by the Star Ferry, a green and white boat that has been coming and going in Victoria Harbour for a century. The details in homage to the boat are mixed in everywhere, from the cabin-like rooms to their numbers, displayed in retro-style lighting. The elevator mirrors, like those in the bathrooms, are shaped like portholes, while the backs of the blue and white benches in the hall are adjustable, like those of the Star Ferry. However, The Fleming does not forget the spirit of Hong Kong that resides there, which we find in the design of the lobby, with its scarlet wall covered with mailboxes, as well as in the corridors and the elevator, dressed in bright red. A guaranteed stay at the roots of contemporary Hong Kong.

The Fleming
41 Fleming Road
Wan Chai
Hong Kong

+852 3607 2288

http://thefleming.com/en/

Rooms: from 1,520 HKD

content.title: Chôm Chôm, a Vietnamese restaurant of reference

introduction.small: In the SoHo district (South of Hollywood Road), this trendy little Vietnamese restaurant will make your stay all the more authentic.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chôm Chôm, a Vietnamese restaurant of reference

paragraphs.text:
The interior design is modern without being flashy, with a central marble counter where you can enjoy your food while watching the chefs at work. The Chôm Chôm dining room is never empty thanks to its unpretentious restyled Vietnamese cuisine made with quality products.

For beef dishes, choose a beef pho roll served in a wok with rice noodles and spinach, or the Lôc Lac. If you prefer chicken, opt for fried Vietnamese-style wings. If you have some room left, try the garlic-fried tiger prawns. The servers are kind and background music is conducive to spending a delicious moment! They do not take reservations, so plan to go right when they open. Otherwise, you can wait a few minutes on the terrace with a glass of Sapporo.

Chôm Chôm
58 Peel Street
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2810 0850

https://www.chomchom.com.hk/

Menu: around 480 HKD

content.title: Ophelia, halfway between dream and reality

introduction.small: In a setting straight out of a dream, Ophelia transports you to the end of the night in Hong Kong.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ophelia, halfway between dream and reality

paragraphs.text:
Wan Chai, on the island of Hong Kong, is a culturally vibrant neighbourhood where many bars can be found. Among them, Ophelia is undoubtedly the most magical and mystical, and perhaps the most exuberant. The place is hidden behind a fake bird shop called Mr Wong's Aviary that is filled with hanging cages. Slip behind the velvet curtain to discover the bar with its peacock feathered walls and wooden and fabric seats in blue and purple tones.

In this aviary design imagined by Ashley Sutton, you will sip exotic cocktails such as the Funk Shui (salt butter caramel whisky and nut liquor topped with a homemade whisky biscuit), brought by waitresses in cheongsam who move on tiptoes. To accompany the potions, order the tapas cooked by the Australian chef Angus Harrison and see how the truffle arancini tastes. Finally, to add to the magical atmosphere of the place, cabarets are put on several nights a week.

Ophelia
Shop F39A & F41A, 1/F
Lee Tung Avenue
200 Queen's Road East
Wan Chai
Hong Kong

+852 2520 1117

www.ophelia.com.hk

Menu: around 200 HKD

content.title: Metropol, a flagship dim sum address

introduction.small: More than a Hong Kong culinary specialty, dim sum represents the soul of Hong Kong cuisine. Meet at the Metropol, one of the emblematic restaurants of the genre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Metropol, a flagship dim sum address

paragraphs.text:
In the huge hall of the Metropol restaurant, located on the fourth floor of a famous Hong Kong shopping centre, you will dine on dim sum in the traditional way. Waiters wander between the tables, pushing carts loaded with fritters and stuffed buns, as well as bamboo baskets containing the famous steamed dumplings.

Wave your hand and one of these many waiters will approach immediately, explaining their delicious treats. Trust your intuition and choose between sweet and savoury dishes. You will not regret your spirit of adventure! Served in small portions, like Spanish tapas, dim sum are shared with family or friends, and served with a bit of green tea, of course.

Metropol Restaurant
4/F, United Centre
95 Queensway
Admiralty
Hong Kong

+852 2865 1988

https://www.facebook.com/pages/%E5%90%8D%E9%83%BD%E9%85%92%E6%A8%93/197325313617481

Menu: from 210 HKD

content.title: The Heritage Museum, indicator of a troubled past

introduction.small: Travel through Hong Kong's history, culture and art with this museum at once entertaining and enlightening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Heritage Museum, indicator of a troubled past

paragraphs.text:
Chinese under the Qing dynasty, then British from 1842 until the retrocession to China in 1997, Hong Kong is constantly evolving. Its troubled past offers a lot in terms of history and influences many contemporary local artists. Located on the banks of the Shing Mun River in a siheyuan – a traditional house built around a patio – the Hong Kong Heritage Museum opened its doors in 2000 to reveal the secrets of this unique culture. Over 7,500 sqm of exhibition areas, you will learn about the history behind the city and the territories, as well as their art and cultures. The museum is spread over several permanent galleries: one is devoted to Cantonese opera, and others to the work of Jin Yong or allowing children to learn while playing for instance. As you exit the museum, make a stop by the Sha Tin park, famous for the “monkey hills” where long-tailed macaques have taken up residence.

Hong Kong Heritage Museum
1 Man Lam Road
Sha Tin
Hong Kong

+852 2180 8188

https://www.heritagemuseum.gov.hk/en_US/web/hm/highlights.html

content.title: Butterfly on Waterfront, window on the world

introduction.small: This slightly futuristic hotel has simple, high-tech rooms with stunning views of the harbour and the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Butterfly on Waterfront, window on the world

paragraphs.text:
Whatever your budget, a stay in Hong Kong should be a unique and totally captivating experience. Staying here, at the top of a tower with stunning views of the skyscrapers and the sea, will make you feel like the star of an action movie. By day or night, the decor is captivating. Once back down to earth, you're only a short walk from the starting point of the ferry to Macau, unless you prefer to stroll in the shopping and restaurant district of Sheung Wan. Either way, you won't get lost as tourist guides and Smartphones for research and local calls are included in every room, which are on the small side, but super high-tech, and very comfortable.

Butterfly on Waterfront
94 Connaught Road West
Sheung Wan
Hong Kong

+852 3559 9988

www.butterflyhk.com

Online reservation only

Rooms: from 1,130 HKD

content.title: Steamy treats at Ding Dim

introduction.small: If you only can eat in one place in Hong Kong, make it this small spot. The dim sum is to die for.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Steamy treats at Ding Dim

paragraphs.text:
Stuck in the middle of touristy restaurants in the expat district is this Hong Kong institution, which for almost 50 years has ruled the dim sum nest. Aficionados of the small steamed dishes will discover here what they're really supposed to taste like. Infinitely light rice dumplings with fillings and toppings of unquestionable freshness, they are incredibly delicious — and copious! So don't be put off by the long queue outside. Ding Dim only has four or five tables, but the turnover is fast. Study the menu while you wait and write down your choices; this will save time once seated. Don't pass on dessert, they're amazing! And if your eyes are bigger than your stomach, don't worry, they will pack up whatever's left into doggy bags.

Ding Dim 1968
59 Wyndham Street
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2326 1968

www.dingdim.com

Menu: around 100 HKD

content.title: Take to the skies at Victoria Peak

introduction.small: Those who haven't climbed up to the Peak do not really know Hong Kong.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take to the skies at Victoria Peak

paragraphs.text:
Quick! Head for the Victoria Peak as soon as you get to Hong Kong. The high point of Hong Kong embraces the magic of the city. As soon as the funicular starts its journey from Central district on a clear day, you are overwhelmed with emotion. The skyscrapers that flash by are unrecognisable.

In the middle of the trip, the spotlight turns to Kowloon and Hong Kong Island. You have the city in your grasp. The summit offers amazing views extending far beyond the territory out to Macau and mainland China. And, surprisingly, you discover the bucolic side of Hong Kong, with its wooded slopes and untouched beaches nestled in the mountains. Take the path of Lugard Road and Harlech Road that winds through the ferns, bamboo, and hibiscus.

The houses hidden there are among the most expensive in the world. Ever since the British governor built his summer home on the cool peak, people have dreamed of moving here. For those who are just visiting, come back at night for a different kind of magic.

Victoria Peak
The Peak Tram
33 Garden Road
Central
Hong Kong

Tel : +852 2522 0922

https://www.thepeak.com.hk/en

content.title: Lin Heung Tea House: a delicious spectacle

introduction.small: Join the crowd and enjoy duck with eight treasures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lin Heung Tea House: a delicious spectacle

paragraphs.text:
Do not leave Hong Kong without a visit to this tea house. It has not changed since 1926, and it appears in the film In the Mood for Love by Wong Kar-wai. Gentlemen come to read the newspaper in the morning and then, little by little, the restaurant awakens and soon the 50 tables are crowded with some 300 guests.

Charming waitresses push their carts among the tables and announce to no one in particular the dishes on offer. Customers hail them or go toward them. The restaurant resounds with a thousand cries. Yet it's a safe bet that this tea house will seduce you, because this is an authentic Hong Kong institution. Customers also celebrate it for its cuisine, including 30 speciality dim sum, a sort of Chinese tapas.

Do not miss the chicken, vegetable, omelette and bacon-strip bun or the duck with eight treasures and moon cakes, which the Lin Heung Tea House is famous for.

Lin Heung Tea House
160-164, Wellington Street
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2544 4556

Menu: around 50 HKD

content.title: Yan Toh Heen: scallops in a bird's nest

introduction.small: Taste exquisite food in jade dishware.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yan Toh Heen: scallops in a bird's nest

paragraphs.text:
You have chosen one of the best Cantonese cuisine restaurants in the world. Yan Toh Heen, one of the restaurants in the Intercontinental, has two Michelin stars. Revamped in 2013, it has new decor, and a new kitchen, but the classics remain, such as Peking Duck, one of the few twists in Cantonese cuisine.

An amazing and huge black marble Chinese seal welcomes you at the entrance, engraved with the restaurant's name reflected on the window underneath. On its tables, equally splendid jade dishes exalt your meal.

Guests come from far away for the divine dim sum, which includes steamed lobster and mango, and steamed crab, avocado and black truffle. And, even rarer, scallops in bird's nest with a gold leaf. As you don't have to limit yourself to dim sum, try wok sautéed shrimp, garnished with white asparagus and a paste of black beans. Here, everything is a delight.

Yan Toh Heen
Intercontinental Hotel
18, Salisbury Road
Hong Kong

+852 2313 2323

https://hongkong-ic.intercontinental.com/en/dining/yan-toh-heen/

Menu: around 800 HKD

content.title: The Peninsula High Tea: Albion has not quite left Hong Kong

introduction.small: Under the eyes of the gargoyles in the lobby, a dashing concerto of violins and scones plays on.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Peninsula High Tea: Albion has not quite left Hong Kong

paragraphs.text:
Ready for a visit to one of the most venerable British institutions in Hong Kong? At the Peninsula, which has always been a player in Hong Kong's history, teatime is paradise.

Between 2:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. in the vast lobby, where gargoyles look out over ivory and gold columns that rise to the ceiling, your tea awaits you. A violin quartet plays discreetly. Savoury cakes come first. There is English bacon, local crab, and delicious organic vegetables. Enjoy the simplicity of some savoury canapés and other pastries, typical of the afternoon teatime at the Peninsula, which is among the best in the world. Rarely will you taste scones quite as exquisite as they are here.

For desserts, English clotted cream from Devonshire, of course. Which goes perfectly with the sublime local fruit jams, organic of course.

High Tea at the Hong Kong Peninsula
Salisbury Road
Hong Kong

+852 2920 2888

https://www.peninsula.com/en/hong-kong/5-star-luxury-hotel-kowloon

Menu: around 398 HKD for one person, 718 HKD for two

content.title: Ho Lee Fook: whatever you feel like eating

introduction.small: A Taiwanese chef by way of Sydney tantalises Hong Kong with fusion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ho Lee Fook: whatever you feel like eating

paragraphs.text:
This is the place to go for dinner with a group of friends. Go to the basement where a peacock mosaic awaits you at the bottom of the stairs. The subdued light that barely disturbs the Instagram projections, and the right kind of rock music in the background promise a happy moment.

Jowett Yu's delicious cuisine backs this up. The Taiwanese chef has enjoyed success in Sydney so Hong Kong was just a matter of time. A total success. Try the char siu pork – a barbecue-like Cantonese cooking technique – or the jackfruit, salted and fried like a piece of meat and served with mellow tofu.

Do not hesitate to seek advice from servers who have taken the time to learn about each dish. The success of Ho Lee Fook, which means ‘good luck to your mouth' in Cantonese, is also based on the great idea of fusion cuisine, which is still rare in Hong Kong.

Ho Lee Fook
1, Elgin Street
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2810 0860

https://www.holeefook.com.hk/

Menu: around 330 HKD

content.title: Join the party at Lan Kwai Fong, an unrivalled Hong Kong specialty

introduction.small: Here, the cosmopolitan party is in full swing like nowhere else in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Join the party at Lan Kwai Fong, an unrivalled Hong Kong specialty

paragraphs.text:
If you're looking for Hong Kong's frenzied fun side, go to Lan Kwai Fong. The alley of the same name now extends to a mini-district with a dozen streets.

It is Hong Kong's most international area with hundreds of bars, restaurants, and clubs. Hongkongers mix with expatriates, who line up in front of antique shops to get into their favourite places. If you want Peruvian food or a Scandinavian dinner at midnight, head to Lan Kwai Fong or Soho, which is nearby.

The district came alive in 1983 when California restaurant opened. Since then, it has been the consummate host of the party. This is where movie stars from China go when they're passing through Hong Kong. In 2013, the South China Morning Post called Lan Kwai Fong in Hong Kong the most romantic place while CNN listed it as one of 10 Hong Kong specialities that is unparalleled on Earth. Go now!

Lan Kwai Fong
Central
Hong Kong

www.lankwaifong.com

content.title: Tai Lung Fung: hobnobbing with Hong Kong movie stars

introduction.small: The recipe for this small cosy bar includes a dose of nostalgia and a little mandarin peel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tai Lung Fung: hobnobbing with Hong Kong movie stars

paragraphs.text:
Go back to 1960s Hong Kong. This is where Sam, Tai Lung Fung's owner, wants to take you. This little old bar became fashionable for its decor of old film posters and equally ancient press clippings.

Tai Lung Fung means ‘great dragon and phoenix', a typically Hong Kong term that means kitsch and cheap at the same time. Sam serves meat with dried tangerine peel, advised by Chinese medicine, and offers cocktails based on lemongrass or chamomile liqueur.

The bar is hidden behind the Blue House, a beautiful wooden house built in 1920 that was recently given heritage status. Tai Lung Fung's warm hospitality is appealing, making it one of Hong Kong's friendliest bars.

Tai Lung Fung
The Archive
5-9, Hing Wan Street
Wan Chai
Hong Kong

+852 2572 0055

https://www.facebook.com/大龍鳳-TAI-LUNG-FUNG-213196412025029/

Drinks: around 45 HKD

content.title: The energy of the city at the W Hong Kong

introduction.small: From the lobby to the pool on the top floor, the W Hong Kong amplifies the buzz of the city, and encourages you to discover it.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The energy of the city at the W Hong Kong

paragraphs.text:
Taking a swim in the outdoor pool at this hotel will give you great pleasure. Installed on the roof on the 76th floor, it has an exceptional view of Hong Kong island. The W Hong Kong, which has 393 rooms, has chosen the motto ‘Anything, any time'. And Hong Kong's bubbling energy permeates the hotel. Rest assured, however, calm reigns in your spacious and airy room.

But the lobby and reception, on the sixth floor, are always crowded. Elsewhere, you would find this oppressive but here, paradoxically, it gives you the energy to go out and explore the wealth of the city. The hotel is well located for tourists and business travellers. It takes three minutes to walk to the International Trade Centre and five minutes to get to the express subway line that links to the international airport. Ready to explore?

W Hong Kong
1 Austin Road
Jordan
Hong Kong

+852 3717 2222

www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/hkgwh-w-hong-kong/

Rooms: from 2,150 HKD

content.title: Hong Kong Disneyland: magic and interactive

introduction.small: Hong Kong Disneyland is seductive day and night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hong Kong Disneyland: magic and interactive

paragraphs.text:
Hong Kong Disneyland is smaller than Orlando and Paris, but it has many advantages. Disneyland opened in China in 2005, and held the first ‘Paint the Night Parade' exhibition ever organised by Disney.

Seven hundred and forty thousand dazzling, coloured lights light up the Hong Kong night against a soundtrack of original Cantonese music. ‘Beauty', in a yellow dress, sits on a four-metre-high throne of lights. Garlands of scintillating rainbow-coloured lights sail through the night sky. ‘Flash McQueen' has never been so beautiful, with dozens of small yellow lights. Do not miss the Lion King, the Mystic Manor or the daily parade.

And the good news is that Hong Kong Disneyland gets bigger every year. Take your children to meet the Disney characters strolling around. With Mickey's interactive brushes, they can change the colour of their costumes in the blink of an eye.

Hong Kong Disneyland
Lantau Island
Hong Kong

+852 3550 3388

https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/?located=true

content.title: The InterContinental, opening up to the sea

introduction.small: Located on the shoreline, the InterContinental offers its guests the splendour of Victoria Harbour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The InterContinental, opening up to the sea

paragraphs.text:
The InterContinental has huge windows in a vast lobby looking out to the magnificent port. Day or night, this panoramic view is one of the most sublime, from the Kowloon side onto Victoria Harbour.

The hallways leading to the rooms are scented with orchids and lotus flowers. Ask for a room overlooking the harbour. Facing the sea, you will lose your sense of time, watching the red-sailed junk sail away. Or, go to the Spa, one of Hong Kong's finest. Its infinity pool, so close to the sea that it seems to be an extension of it, will give you the feeling of swimming in the bay. The hotel service goes hand in hand, of course, with the hotel's pure refinement.

Finally, at the daily magic hour of the Symphony of Lights, the lobby is the best place to enjoy a unique view while sipping sumptuous cocktails.

InterContinental Hong Kong
18, Salisbury Road
Tsim Sha Tsui
Hong Kong

+852 2721 1211

https://www.ihg.com/intercontinental/hotels/gb/en/hong-kong/hkghc/hoteldetail

Rooms: from 1,580 HKD

content.title: Sugar at East Hotel: at 180 degrees, this sugar will make you melt

introduction.small: On the 32nd floor, grilled farm sausages, refreshing cocktails and DJ Eric Byron.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sugar at East Hotel: at 180 degrees, this sugar will make you melt

paragraphs.text:
The 180-degree view of the harbour is sensational. Enjoy it, nestled in one of the plush sofas on the outdoor terrace. From the 32nd floor of the East Hotel, the slew of skyscrapers below seems very modest indeed. With 3,000 sqm, Sugar strikes a balance between its relaxed Scandinavian vibe and its hyped-up reputation as one of the city's nocturnal hot spots.

The current star-cocktail is the East Side. With a blend of gin, lemon, mint and cucumber, it brings a timely refreshing feeling.

Sugar also serves tasty tapas, such as goat cheese sandwiches, farm sausages and beef rillettes. Sugar always has a line-up of top DJs, including Eric Byron, a star in Asia.

Sugar
East Hotel, 32nd floor
29, Taikoo Shing Road
Taikoo Shing
Hong Kong

+852 3968 3738

https://www.east-hongkong.com/en/restaurants-and-bars/sugar

Drinks: around 90 HKD

content.title: Eating seafood and shellfish on Lamma Island

introduction.small: Be sure to eat fish from the South China Sea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Eating seafood and shellfish on Lamma Island

paragraphs.text:
What to eat after a swim or a hike on Lamma Island? Seafood and fish, of course. Choose your meal from the large aquariums in the restaurants on stilts at Yung Shue Wan port on the west coast. Freshness is guaranteed. Lobsters, clams, bass, and groupers are available in abundance, and you pay by weight.

Your taste buds will not resist steamed scallops and razor clams topped with finely chopped garlic and ginger. Let yourself be tempted by fried oysters or shrimp cooked in rice wine. At Lamma, seafood and fish are prepared numerous ways: sautéed, steamed, baked, raw, sliced, diced…

And for a unique experience, try lobster gratin topped with cheese, a classic hit in Cantonese cuisine.

www.discoverhongkong.com

Menu: around 170 HKD

content.title: The Tin Hau Temple in Repulse Bay: go into the sea and postpone death

introduction.small: The goddess Tin Hau on the shore protects fishermen, offering her ‘bridge of Longevity'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Tin Hau Temple in Repulse Bay: go into the sea and postpone death

paragraphs.text:
Hong Kong has been building polders for a long time; hence, the temples once located on its shores have been moved. This applies to Tin Hau, goddess of the sky and the sea, and protector of fishermen. The territory has over 300 temples dedicated to the goddess.

Among the most visited is the temple at Repulse Bay, which is by the sea. Go up the steps with the two huge statues. The one of Tin Hau shows the goddess in a yellow tunic decorated with waves, her hands wisely folded on her chest. The statue in front of it is of Kwun Yam, a Taoist deity, standing elegantly in his grey tunic.

God monkeys, goldfish, and multicoloured dragons inhabit the area around the temple. Many tourists from the Republic of China come to pray at the graceful little red altars in front of Tin Hau. And no one hesitates to get wet feet when crossing the bridge of Longevity: each time you cross the bridge you prolong your life by three days!

Tin Hau Temple
Beach Road
Hong Kong Island
Hong Kong

content.title: The Luxe Manor: a mansion in the city jungle

introduction.small: You may never want to leave The Luxe Manor after experiencing the warm hospitality of this jewel. Fortunately, the nearby shops in Tsim Sha Tsui beckon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Luxe Manor: a mansion in the city jungle

paragraphs.text:
The hotel is like a ‘castle lost in the urban jungle.' Its pale stone facade hides a sumptuous Chinese door in flaming red. The door opens on to this refined manor. The hotel's public areas are decorated with gold and vermeil friezes.

Your room will stun you with its dreamlike decor, very much influenced by Salvador Dalí. The setting of the Luxe Manor is enchanting, an experience heightened by the staff's attentiveness. Have a picture taken of yourself at your arrival and your departure. And every evening, a delicious little cake awaits you in your room. Step outside your rain spa shower to a whole host of soft towels folded into cute animal shapes.

The bed linens are, of course, exquisite. Have a delicious Earl Grey tea martini before going shopping in Tsim Sha Tsui, home to a thousand shops.

The Luxe Manor
39 Kimberley Road
Tsim Sha Tsui
Hong Kong

+852 3763 8888

https://www.theluxemanor.com/default-en.html

Rooms: from 930 HKD

content.title: Enjoy Hong Kong until the very last minute at the Icon Hotel

introduction.small: Near the Science Museum, this hotel, whose staff is partially made up of students at the nearby University, welcomes you in a refined setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy Hong Kong until the very last minute at the Icon Hotel

paragraphs.text:
This hotel belongs to the Hong Kong Polytechnic University, which is located just steps away. It is based on an original concept: the university's students form part of the staff, and all perform with great professionalism. They are very attentive, and the hospitality is refined.

The lobby oscillates between the Eastern aesthetic of fashion designer Vivienne Tam and the Western design sense of Sir Terence Conran. The majestic curved staircase of glass and steel leads up to a living wall on the first floor, designed by vertical garden inventor Patrick Blanc. The rooms are bright and furnished with sleek furniture, often in blonde wood.

Enjoy the beautiful view of the harbour. And enjoy your stay in Hong Kong until the last minute: even after you've paid your bill you can stay in a large living-room area provided with chic individual lockers, good-sized showers, towel service, and baskets of fruit.

Icon Hotel
17, Science Museum Road
Tsim Sha Tsui East
Hong Kong

+852 3400 1000

www.hotel-icon.com

Rooms: from 1,320 HKD

content.title: Take the Star Ferry during the Symphony of Lights show

introduction.small: Every night at 8:00 p.m., get on board for the biggest and most beautiful illuminations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take the Star Ferry during the Symphony of Lights show

paragraphs.text:
A city with such great skyscrapers should show them off. Every night, starting at 8:00 p.m., lasers and searchlights sweep the facade of the buildings to a musical soundtrack. The show lasts 13 minutes. To make the most of it, cross Victoria Bay on a ferry that features dinner and dancing. The Symphony of Lights illuminates not only the skyscrapers of Hong Kong Island, but also those of Tsim Sha Tsui, in Kowloon, on the other side. A heart-stopping show that will undoubtedly delight all kids.

A total of 47 skyscrapers metamorphose under the exuberant, swirling graphic effects, crazy lights, and graceful Asian motifs. Hong Kong celebrates its energy centre-stage. And, so it should.

Symphony of Lights
Star Ferry Pier, Kowloon Point
Tsim Sha Tsui
Kowloon
Hong Kong

+852 2367 7065

www.starferry.com.hk/en/home

content.title: Hong Kong: Temple of Electronics

introduction.small: Why restrict yourself in one of the biggest shopping paradises on earth?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hong Kong: Temple of Electronics

paragraphs.text:
In a city where everyone uses a smartphone or tablet, electronic shops abound.

Moreover, Hong Kong has duty-free port status and two long sales periods, from July to September and December to February. Whether you're looking for phones, computer equipment, or cameras, Hong Kong will surely satisfy you. There are even preview products.

The shops in Tsim Sha Tsui, Causeway Bay, and Mong Kok have the most competitive prices. Make sure that the warranty is international and check that your video equipment is compatible with your country's electrical current. Give in to a shopping spree – there is no other place where you can get such great bargains.

content.title: The Chi Lin Nunnery: without nails but not without beauty

introduction.small: Buddha deserves this wooden pegged architectural miracle of serenity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Chi Lin Nunnery: without nails but not without beauty

paragraphs.text:
Surely, one of the most beautiful places in Hong Kong, if off the beaten track. The Chi Lin Nunnery, built on 33,000 square metres following the precepts of feng shui, is a splendid lesson on architecture and Chinese civilisation. And, Buddhism as well.

Built in 1934 and renovated in 1990 according to ancient Tang Dynasty (618-907) blueprints, its 95,000 pieces of wood are held together without a single nail. Enter through the shanmen, the door to the mountain, and be enchanted by the temples and gardens. The beauty of the place is apparent from the first courtyard, decorated with basins, blooming lotus flowers, magnificent bonsai, and rock gardens.

At the other end, you reach the Temple of Heavenly Kings, which serves as the reception room to the nunnery. Large golden Buddhas punctuate the visit that leads to the spectacular main temple. Twenty-eight yellow cedar columns support a roof covered with 28,000 tiles. Soak up the serenity of the nunnery before diving back into the frenzy of the city centre.

Chi Lin Nunnery
5, Chi Lin Drive
Diamond Hill
Kowloon
Hong Kong

+852 2354 1888

www.chilin.org

content.title: Put on your swimsuit and fly to the Hotel Indigo Hong Kong Island

introduction.small: It has a glass-bottomed pool in the sky, but that's not this hotel's only draw.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Put on your swimsuit and fly to the Hotel Indigo Hong Kong Island

paragraphs.text:
Up on the top floor, 27 stories up, a spectacular glass-bottomed swimming pool cantilevers directly out above the street. You feel like you're swimming in the sky, high above the cars.

Keep that feeling of living in the sky by staying in a corner room on the upper floors, with stunning views of Victoria Peak. Each floor has only eight rooms. The hotel's calm, private ambience is enhanced by the extremely discreet and effective staff. The bed linens are perfect, and rooms harmonise colourful Western design with elegant Chinese handicrafts.

If you stay at Indigo on your birthday, a beautiful cake will be waiting in your room. The hotel offers a quiet room to shower in before leaving for the airport.

Hotel Indigo Hong Kong Island
246 Queen's Road
East Wanchai
Hong Kong

+852 3926 3888

https://www.ihg.com/hotelindigo/hotels/us/en/hong-kong/hkgin/hoteldetail?cm_mmc=GoogleMaps-_-IN-_-HK-_-HKGIN

Rooms: from 1,372 HKD

content.title: Indulge in a foot massage

introduction.small: Here, one goes to the reflexologist as one goes to the hairdresser. In Hong Kong, health begins with the feet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Indulge in a foot massage

paragraphs.text:
Instead of getting a foot massage just before leaving Hong Kong, why not have one at the beginning of your stay? A good one will lessen the effects of jet lag by restoring your body's energy flows.

Hong Kong has excellent reflexologists who charge much less than many of their colleagues elsewhere in the world. Your therapist, whose practice is based on over a thousand years of observation and care in Chinese medicine, presses on specific points on the body that are remotely connected to other parts of the body.

The session takes place in a specific order: grip, joint release, stretching, smoothing the feet, massaging the toes and metatarsals, and then massage in order to treat reflex points. Don't plan anything hectic for after your massage and don't blush if you fall asleep during the session.

Reflexology Sanctuary
137-141 Queen's Road Central
Central
Hong Kong

+852 2971 1010

http://tenfeettall.com.hk/

content.title: Mira Moon Hotel: lushly populated by rabbits and peonies

introduction.small: The Mira Hotel Moon transforms Chinese mythology into splendid contemporary design, combined with the most advanced technologies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mira Moon Hotel: lushly populated by rabbits and peonies

paragraphs.text:
Inspired by Chinese mythology, architect Marcel Wanders has interpreted it with elegant kitsch. The lobby at Mira Moon will seduce you.

Delightful bunnies decorate the walls, lamps, and refined carpets. For the Chinese, the rabbit is equivalent to the man on the moon. And splendid pink peonies decorate everything from bathroom tiles and the mirror in your room to your bathrobe. The contemporary furniture is stylish and comfortable.

The reception provides guests with their own Smartphones for the ultimate in convenience. And calls to most countries are free. The hotel also has a digital newsstand with free access to more than 2,000 newspapers in 56 languages. At the Mira Moon, living in Hong Kong is like living at home.

Mira Moon Hotel
388 Jaffe Road
Causeway Bay
Hong Kong

+852 2643 8888

www.miramoonhotel.com

Rooms: from 1,330 HKD

content.title: Ladies Market: for men too

introduction.small: Thousands of articles to politely haggle over can be found at the Ladies Market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ladies Market: for men too

paragraphs.text:
Imagine a kilometre of streets lined with at least 100 shops. This is the Ladies Market, which is not quite what its name suggests, as an increasing amount of men's clothing is available here, too. Besides T-shirts and suits for gentlemen, you can buy cheap women's clothing, silk scarves, cosmetics, toys, watches, decorative items, etc.

Not to mention a multitude of very cheap iPhone cases, which, for some reason, are available nowhere else in Hong Kong. Do not be afraid to bargain. There are many salespeople and they welcome you with utmost courtesy.

Do not hesitate to venture into parallel streets where you can find very good electronic equipment for very low prices. Without realising it, you can spend a whole day at the Ladies Market. Fortunately, there are many restaurants all around.

Ladies Market
Tung Choi Street
Mong Kok
Hong Kong

https://www.ladies-market.hk/

content.title: Better than Manhattan, discover Hong Kong by helicopter

introduction.small: Travel from skyscrapers to pristine beaches, and make a quick trip to Macau, too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Better than Manhattan, discover Hong Kong by helicopter

paragraphs.text:
Take off from the 30th floor of the Peninsula Hotel, whether you are a hotel guest or not. Heliservices and Peninsula are sister companies who partnered on this business venture. Face-to-face with the surrounding skyscrapers, you will find yourself standing almost on equal footing with them and feel an incredible emotion. And do not tell the pilot that only Manhattan in New York offers the same rapturous experience. He will tell you that the U.S. authorities have introduced much stricter overview standards.

In Hong Kong, you can get up close to the skyscrapers, including the tallest tower, the International Trade Centre (ICC) and its 118 floors. And you will find that the territory is not just a bustling city but also the countryside, mountains, and deserted beaches.

Yet, curiously, the city is gradually chipping away at the mountains, especially that of Victoria Peak. It is as if the prestigious estates on its flanks want to climb to the top…

Peninsula Hotel
Suite 1801, 18th floor
Chinachem Johnston Plaza
178-186, Johnston Road
Wanchai
Hong Kong

+852 2802 0200

http://heliservices.com.hk/en/

content.title: Nan Lian Garden: gold and lotus

introduction.small: Nan Lian shows us how China contributed to the art of gardening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nan Lian Garden: gold and lotus

paragraphs.text:
The harmony of the garden immediately charms you. Visiting the garden with a guide can be useful and enhance your emotion, as this place is a rarity in the art of the Chinese garden.

It incorporates the traditional style of the Jiangshouju garden in Shanxi, the only one developed during the Tang Dynasty (618-907) that remains true to its original design today. Feng shui not the only guiding principle at Nan Lian Garden; everything was carefully thought out. Make your way at your own pace through small trails that lead to the waterfall and lake, where the air is perfumed with lilac and jasmine. And see how the millennial rocks have been integrated into the design. Two small elegant vermilion bridges span the lotus pond, leading to the garden's centrepiece, the golden Pavilion of Absolute Perfection.

Visit the vegetarian restaurant for a delicious break-it is next to the waterfall.

Nan Lian Garden
60, Fung Tak Road
Diamond Hill
Kowloon
Hong Kong

+852 3658 9366

www.nanliangarden.org

content.title: Temple Street Night Market: Night of the Hunter

introduction.small: Go into the night, amongst opera singers and fortune-tellers, in search of Chinese antiques or objects of today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Temple Street Night Market: Night of the Hunter

paragraphs.text:
What's the difference between Temple Street Night Market and others? Atmosphere. Everyone's bargaining, of course. But there's also a host of other things to do. Like visit a fortune-teller, who can tell your future from not just your hands, but your face.

And listen to Cantonese opera singers, amateurs for the most part, accompanied by musicians. Browse through the market in the early evening. Then, dine in one of the small restaurants offering seafood of exquisite freshness, frequented mostly by Hong Kong natives.

And what is there to buy? Besides clothes and electronics, there are Chinese opium pipes, acupuncturist boxes, jade, relics from the Maoist era… and selfie sticks. At Temple Street, mingle with the locals at night, in a quiet atmosphere, away from the diurnal agitation.

Temple Street Night Market
Temple Street
Yau Ma Tei
Hong Kong

content.title: Strolling in Soho: but what are the police doing here?

introduction.small: The latest trendy neighbourhood, Soho has attracted stylists who have taken over former police headquarters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Strolling in Soho: but what are the police doing here?

paragraphs.text:
Soho stands for South of Hollywood Boulevard. Located just behind Central, it has recently become very fashionable. In its narrow streets, traditional shops have given way to more modern stores, cafés, restaurants, and art galleries.

If you are looking for stylists and avant-garde artists, go to Soho. If you want to discover the best antique stores, go to Soho. If you fancy partying late into the night, go to Soho. Irish pubs rub shoulders with restaurants boasting cuisines from around the world, including two Nepalese places that serve beer from the homeland.

Do not miss the Police Married Quarters (PMQ), formerly housing for police officers and their families that has been cleverly converted into a hundred small stores, many of them decorative. In addition to being a good alternative to huge shopping centres, charming Soho is also a great place to check out the soup kitchens, which have not yet disappeared from its streets.

Soho
Central
Hong Kong

www.ilovesoho.hk

content.title: Sik Sik Yuen Wong Tai Sin Temple: ask the world

introduction.small: Followers of Tao, Confucius and Buddha came to visit the generous monk, Wong Tai Sin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sik Sik Yuen Wong Tai Sin Temple: ask the world

paragraphs.text:
Wong Tai Sin, a monk who lived in the fourth century, ‘fulfilled wishes on request', according to legend. And, so, a faithful crowd comes each day to honour him in this temple where, in 1915, another monk placed a sacred portrait of Wong Tai Sin. Come in. There is nothing stuffy about the place.

Followers and the merely curious wander happily in gardens around the temple while music plays. Wong Tai Sin did not require silence from those who came to him with offerings or for a divination session. Because in the Garden of Good Wishes, you can indulge in kaucim.

The game is to shake a tube containing 100 divination sticks until one drops out. A geomancer then reads it. It remains to be seen whether your wish comes true. And, not necessarily immediately!

SikSik Yuen Wong Tai Sin Temple
2, Chuk Yuen Village
Wong Tai Sin
Kowloon
Hong Kong

+852 2327 8141

www1.siksikyuen.org.hk/en/siksikyuen-home

content.title: Tai O Heritage Hotel : the magic of an idyllic landscape

introduction.small: With the pirates gone, the Customs Office has been transformed into a beautiful romantic hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tai O Heritage Hotel : the magic of an idyllic landscape

paragraphs.text:
To forget the stress of city living, head to the charming village of Tai O on Lantau Island. Within minutes of landing, the nine rooms at Tai O Heritage Hotel await.

This former British customs station, built in 1902 to fight against pirates, was restored in 2012, watchtowers and guns included. From your sober colonial-style room, admire magnificent sunsets and go to sleep to the murmuring sea below. Off in the distance, beautiful pink dolphins gambol. Take a fishermen's skiff out there and join them. Or, perhaps you prefer the picturesque landscape on the opposite bank with the different greens of the hills.

This is the perfect place for a romantic getaway.

Tai O Heritage Hotel
Shek Tsai Po Street
Tai O
Lantau Island
Hong Kong

+852 2985 8383

www.taioheritagehotel.com

Rooms: from 1,900 HKD

content.title: Be amazed by the Swedish mystery of the Tuve Hotel

introduction.small: Located close to Victoria Park, the Tuve is a unique and refreshing change of scenery. Dare to cross the threshold.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Be amazed by the Swedish mystery of the Tuve Hotel

paragraphs.text:
The hotel's architect chose Hong Kong for his ode to Lake Tuve in Sweden. He has transposed his emotions about the lake into the hotel's design, with the result being one of the very few minimalist buildings in the city.

It promises a unique experience even before you have entered. There is no sign to the reception, which is on the second floor of this beautiful edifice in Causeway Bay. ‘We wanted to play with the sense of exploration and discovery for our guests,' said the designer. Do not be intimidated by the large sculpted iron wall at the entrance, nor the dark corridors. They hide a haven of peace in the heart of the city.

Each floor has only three rooms, all very comfortable. Enjoy the wide beds, and relax in the beautiful marble bathrooms. The minimalist design will bring a certain freshness to your stay, contrasting nicely with the dampness of the city. A rarity.

Tuve Hotel
16, Tsing Fung Street
Causeway Bay
Hong Kong

+852 3995 8899

https://www.tuve.hk/

Rooms: from 863 HKD

content.title: Go to the beach at Repulse Bay and look for the dragon

introduction.small: Get out of the city and head for the white sands of Repulse Bay, which has lost none of its charms of yesteryear—nor its lurking dragon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Go to the beach at Repulse Bay and look for the dragon

paragraphs.text:
Named after a British ship, the Repulse, which helped hunt pirates in the region in the 19th century, Repulse Bay has long been a vacation spot for rich Hong Kongers. Admire the beautiful vestiges of colonial splendour, including the hotel, The Verandah, in its green setting. It is now the seaside annex of the prestigious Peninsula hotel.

In winter, which is never too cold in Hong Kong, the hotel offers a rarity: a fondue simmering over the open fire of the large fireplace in the lounge. But, do as the swimmers do and enjoy Repulse Bay for its white sand beach, one of the finest and most extensive in Hong Kong.

The soft green mountains of the South China Sea protect the bay, accentuating its charm. And do not miss the curious building on the seafront. The hollowed-out centre is designed to let the dragon go through, so he can go drink from the sea…

Repulse Bay Beach
Beach Road
Hong Kong

+852 2812 2483

https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/beach/index/beach-location-hk/beach-address-south.html#repulsebay

content.title: Hong Kong Museum of History: mirror, mirror on the wall

introduction.small: From the Devonian period to movie stars, Hong Kong delves brilliantly into its past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hong Kong Museum of History: mirror, mirror on the wall

paragraphs.text:
Few cities in the world have as complete and as interesting a museum about their past and their present. The Hong Kong Museum of History brings you back 400 million years to the Devonian Era, when the territory was a vast alluvial plain. Then came the first Hong Kong hominids, represented with the reconstruction of a lakeside village diorama.

One of eight rooms presents the fascinating Chinese dynasties. There is also a folk museum component, comprising the different ethnic groups of southern China. Among the objects on display is a life-sized junk. There is also a life-sized reconstruction of a street in the Central district from 1881. Numerous interactive activities will entertain your kids.

Themes like the opium wars, and Hong Kong's relationship with Japan, imperial China, and the British precede a beautiful exhibition dedicated to the local cinema and its stars. A delight for the entire family.

Hong Kong Museum of History
100, Chatham Road South
Tsim Sha Tsui
Kowloon
Hong Kong

+852 2724 9042

https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/Museum/History/en_US/web/mh/index.html

content.title: A day in Macau: where cod meets lotus flower!

introduction.small: Portugal and China merge to the nostalgic tune of saudade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A day in Macau: where cod meets lotus flower!

paragraphs.text:
Try it: greet the Chinese customs official with bom dia, 'hello' in Portuguese. Surprised, he will say the same thing back to you with a smile. In 1999, Portugal returned Macau to China, but Portugal's soul never left this town.

You can still savour the small cinnamon flans the Portuguese passed down to all their former colonies and feast on fusion cooking like nowhere else in the world. How about cod with lotus flower? Stroll past the pastel houses in the historic centre, declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The gentle melancholy of Portugal pervades, mingled with Asian incense. With any luck, you might walk into a church and find a mixed-race portrait of baby Jesus with Chinese features.

And, in the evening, betake yourself to the City of Dreams casino, and see The House of Dancing Water, a love story with 80 artists played out amid grandiose fountains in a basin the size of five Olympic swimming pools!

Macau Tourism Office
Alameda Dr. Carlos d'Assumpçao, n. 335-341
Macao

+853 2831 5566

https://www.macaotourism.gov.mo/en/

content.title: Aqua Luna: a red veil on the sea

introduction.small: The best way to get to know a port is by going on its most emblematic boat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aqua Luna: a red veil on the sea

paragraphs.text:
Hong Kong inspires nostalgia for the elegant purple-sailed junks that once floated in the port. It also inspires a desire to see the city from a rare perspective. Which is why the Aqua Luna is for you. This magnificent junk, which has become a symbol of Hong Kong, sails every day of the week.

Monday to Friday, during the day, it remains in the bay of Hong Kong, and drops you off anyplace that has sea access. On Saturday and Sunday, she goes to the other side of the island, to the beaches in the south and to Stanley.

But, every night, she returns to Hong Kong harbour to offer the best views of the magical Symphony of Lights. With its recognisable red sail, the Aqua Luna is as popular an attraction as the light show itself.

Aqua Luna
Tsim Sha Tsui Public Pier 1
Tsim Sha Tsui
Hong Kong

+852 2116 8821

https://aqualuna.com.hk

content.title: Ocean Park Hong Kong: 80 hectares of emotion

introduction.small: Do you prefer a coral reef, panda conservation, or a 60-metre free fall?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ocean Park Hong Kong: 80 hectares of emotion

paragraphs.text:
Ocean Park is extravagant, and that suits it perfectly. With 80 hectares between sea and mountains, it has a marine aquarium, a zoo, and an amusement park, all three of the very highest calibre.

Visit the Butterfly House, a huge glass cocoon that contains thousands of butterflies. The Reef Atoll is a huge aquarium that reproduces the ecosystem of the Indo-Pacific basin—a coral reef there is home to more than 2,000 marine creatures of 250 species.

For its two residents, the Giant Panda Habitat Club reproduced the Sichuan climate in an enclosed space. There are scientific programmes to prevent the disappearance of the species. And what about The Abyss, which offers a free fall of 60 metres, the equivalent of 20 storeys? Parents and children will be amazed by the 30 attractions on offer.

Ocean Park Hong Kong
Wong Chuk Hang
Hong Kong

+852 3923 2323

https://www.oceanpark.com.hk/en

content.title: Do not be afraid: the great Tian Tan Buddha will protect you

introduction.small: Buddhist art can change your life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Do not be afraid: the great Tian Tan Buddha will protect you

paragraphs.text:
You will find it after climbing up the wooded hill of Ngong Ping plateau, where three monks in the early 20th century founded a humble home, now named the Po Lin Monastery. It is also known as the Monastery of 'Precious Lotus'.

The Tian Tan Buddha, or “Big Buddha Temple of Heaven”, was built here in 1993, proof of the continued vitality of Chinese spirituality. Looking toward Beijing, it sits on a throne of lotus, the Buddhist symbol of purity. Climb the 260 stairs that lead up to him from the monastery to get a closer look at his throne and some of the 220 bronze pieces that it is made from. Then go back down and contemplate it from below.

Take time to experience the serenity that emanates from his person. His right hand raised, palm facing outward, fingers extended upward, indicates the absence of fear and the presence of protection. It transmits the tranquillity of the Buddha to those who will receive it. For more earthly pleasures, the monastery's vegetarian restaurant prepares delicious dishes.

Tian Tan Buddha
Ngong Ping
Lantau Island
Outlying Islands

+852 2985 52 48

www.plm.org.hk/eng/home.php

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Hong Kong
content.introduction: Hong Kong has a monsoon-influenced subtropical climate. Winters are mild and the skies are often cloudy, although it rarely rains. The spring and summer are hot, humid and rainy. Between June and September, the city experiences periods of extreme heat, with temperatures often above 30°C (86°F) and frequent summer showers. Autumn is the sunniest season, with mild temperatures.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Hong-Kong is the Hong-Kong Dollar (HKD).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Hong Kong International Airport
airports.description:
The Hong Kong International Airport is located about 34 kilometres (21 miles) north-west of Hong Kong Island.
  • Two terminals
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Hong Kong and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via A8 freeway.
    • Two parking spaces are available (P1 and P4), with rates ranging between HKD 20 for 1 hour and HKD 160 for 24 hours.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall as well as in the Ground Transportation Centre, on the underground level.
  • By rail
    • Airport Express trains connect Terminal 2 with the city centre about every 10 minutes from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m., with a travel time of about 25 minutes (HKD 115 each way).
  • By bus
    • Several bus lines connect the airport to the centre of the city, with night service after midnight. Travel time is about 30 minutes and fares range from HKD 15 to 48.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available outside the arrivals hall, using a colour code depending on their destinations: Red (Hong Kong Island), Green (New Territories), and Blue (Lantau Island), with fares ranging from HKD 320 to 395.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +852 2181 8888
  • Website: www.hongkongairport.com

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Hong Kong
transportation.description: Hong Kong covers quite a large area. And yet, getting around the city is easy and enjoyable, due to its highly developed, affordable, efficient and convenient public transport system.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Hong Kong, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Hong Kong Tourism Board
information.description:
Offers practical information and many useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Telephone: +852 2508 1234
  • Website: www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/index.jsp

information.title: Visitor information centres operated by the Hong Kong Tourism Board
information.description:
At various locations throughout the city, the Hong Kong Tourism Board operates centres where you can obtain information and recommendations for your stay in Hong Kong. Listed below are the main addresses for the HKTB's visitor information centres :

  • Hong Kong Island Visitor Center: The Peak Piazza
  • Kowloon Visitor Center: Star ferry Concourse, Tsim Sha Tsui
  • Lo Wu Information Center: 2/F Arrival hall, Lon Wu
  • International Airport Visitor Center: Buffer Halls A & B, Arrival level, Terminal 1, Hong Kong International Airport, Lantau Island

information.title: China travel guide
information.description:
The official website of the China National Tourist Office (CNTO) provides a wealth of information on Hong Kong.

Website: www.cnto.org

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Hong Kong counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Chinese phrases that will make your stay in Hong Kong a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Nǐ hǎo
Could you repeat ?: Máfan nín zài chóngfù yībiàn
What time is it ?: Qǐngwèn xiànzài jǐ diǎn ?
Do you have (…)?: Qǐngwèn nín yǒu ma (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Qǐngwèn nǎlǐ kěyǐ zhǎodào (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Qǐngwèn nǎlǐ kěyǐ mǎi dào (...) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Hong Kong
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Hong Kong each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January or February: Chinese New Year (national)
events.description: For three days, celebrations involve merrymaking and entertainment of many kinds, both at home with family members and outside in the streets: firecrackers to ward off evil spirits and demons, fireworks, etc. No effort is spared to celebrate the start of the new lunar year in style.

events.title: February or March: Lantern Festival (Yuanxiao Jie, national)
events.description: Colourful paper lanterns line the streets of Hong Kong and throughout China on this day. Children and adults parade through the city carrying long bamboo poles hung with smaller lanterns.

events.title: August – seventh day of the seventh lunar month : Double seventh festival (Qixi, national)
events.description: Also known as the Chinese Valentine's Day, this romantic tradition has been celebrated in China for centuries, from the time when young, single women prayed for a husband. The name of the festival refers to the seventh daughter of the Jade Emperor, a weaving maid, who was only allowed by her father to see her beloved once a year, on the seventh day of the seventh lunar month. Gifts of bouquets of flowers or chocolates, special dates, romantic dinners, and dance parties are among the celebrations during this day, highly anticipated by all single people in Hong Kong.

events.title: September or October – Fifteenth day of the eighth lunar month : Mid-Autumn Festival (Zhongqiu Jie, national)
events.description: Also known as the Moon Festival, this is the day in the year when the moon is particularly round and bright, a symbol of unity and familial happiness. The main feature of this traditional celebration is the sharing of cakes with family and friends.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Hong Kong
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need a visa to enter Hong Kong. On the other hand, if you plan to travel to mainland China, you will need to be in possession of a Chinese visa, which must be obtained before leaving France. Your passport must be valid for at least six months from your date of arrival in the country.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Hong Kong, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel advisory information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Hong Kong page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/hong-kong/

usefulAddresses.title: Chinese Embassy in France
usefulAddresses.description:
• Address: 11, avenue George V, 75008 Paris
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 49 52 19 50
  • Website: www.amb-chine.fr/fra

French Consulate General in Hong Kong
usefulAddresses.description:

  • Telephone: +852 3752 99 00
  • Website: https://hongkong.consulfrance.org/-English-

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERNMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., Saturday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Sunday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: No daylight savings time in China.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Tipping is not expected in Hong Kong's restaurants and cafés. On the other hand, it is quite common to thank tour guides and drivers by offering a small gratuity. Of course, the amount you choose to give is entirely up to you.
